sentences.english: How quickly their shrieks of pain turn to enraptured adulation.
sentences.chinese: 它們痛苦的尖叫迅速轉變成對吾等恩賜的狂熱諂媚。

sentences.english: A good man should disdain flatterers.
He had a cringing manner but a very harsh voice.
sentences.chinese: 他有卑屈諂媚的神情，但是聲音卻十分粗沙。

sentences.english: And parents or brother elder sister is flattering object you today.
sentences.chinese: 而父母或兄姐就是你今天諂媚的對象了。

sentences.english: But then they would flatter him with their mouths, lying to him with their tongues;
sentences.chinese: 他們卻用口諂媚他，用舌向他說謊。

sentences.english: He is obsequious to men in power.
Many flattering relatives fawned on the rich old man.
sentences.chinese: 許多好諂媚的親戚支巴結那個富有的老人。

sentences.english: I linger in front of an immigration officer with a sycophantic look on my face.
sentences.chinese: 我帶着諂媚的表情在一間入境辦公室門前徘徊着。

sentences.english: They came backstage afterward, cooing and toadying to him.
sentences.chinese: 她們隨後來到後臺，對他嬌語諂媚。

sentences.english: Don't toady to or be obsequious to rich or powerful people.
sentences.chinese: 不諂媚奉承有錢或權勢的人。

sentences.english: They always hold that we are flatterers around the king.
sentences.chinese: 他們總是認爲，我們是君王前狡詐諂媚之輩。

sentences.english: To seek favor or attention by flattery and obsequious behavior .
sentences.chinese: 用拍馬屁和諂媚的態度來取悅，引起注意。

sentences.english: To keep thee from the evil woman, from the flattery of the tongue of a strange woman.
sentences.chinese: 能保你遠離惡婦，遠離外女諂媚的舌頭。

sentences.english: Being a multi-selling megastar hasn't always been mass adoration and adulation.
sentences.chinese: 作爲多產的巨星並不總是有大衆崇拜和諂媚。

sentences.english: Chandler's weasel face screwed into an obsequious smile.
sentences.chinese: 錢德勒黃鼠狼似的臉上現出了諂媚的笑容。

sentences.english: I'm loving hug, also is no match for her a smile.
sentences.chinese: 我再蜜意的擁抱，也敵不外她諂媚的一笑。

definition: to put on an act (idiom); to show affectation/to indulge in histrionics
to ingratiate oneself with/to pander to
by fair means or foul/by hook or by crook/unscrupulously
to curry favor (idiom); playing up to those in power/social climbing
elated/light and airy feeling (after a few drinks)/smug and conceited/complacent
Han Fei, also known as Han Feizi 韓非子|韩非子[Han2 Fei1 zi3] (c. 280-233 BC), Legalist philosopher of the Warring States Period (475-220 BC)
